stream_context.summary: Kaze primarily focused on programming a new 'Raven' enemy for the game's ice level. The process involved implementing its behavior based on team feedback, creating its ice-like appearance, and debugging numerous technical issues with its movement and spawning. He also discussed a potential change to the game's dive jump mechanic based on external feedback.

development_findings.summary: Kaze spent time refactoring the game's codebase, which improved stability, fixed numerous crashes, and got the game running on N64 hardware again.
The ice level is planned to be a surreal ice palace with disorienting or reality-bending elements, though the visuals are currently just debug placeholders.
development_findings.quote: It's gonna be kind of like a surreal ice palace with some mindfuck stuff going on.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is considering nerfing the dive jump mechanic based on feedback from developer Dan Salvato, who argued that allowing players to easily change direction mid-air violates the original game's philosophy of commitment in jumps.
development_findings.quote: I talked to Dan Salvato and he said that the dive jump we have is kind of like against the design of Mario 64 and I can kind of see it.

development_findings.summary: A new Raven enemy was implemented, with its behavior changing from complex path-following to spawning out of surfaces, walking a short distance, and despawning, based on a suggestion from Biobak.
Kaze spent significant time debugging the Raven's movement, which was ultimately caused by a simple typo (a missing plus sign) that moved all enemies to the level's origin point.
development_findings.quote: I forgot the plus. Why did no one tell me? I moved all of them to the level origin. That was the issue the whole time.

development_findings.summary: Kaze identified and fixed a bug where enemy parameters were incorrect due to an order of operations issue in the Fast64 compiler, which required adding extra brackets to the code.
development_findings.quote: This is a fast 64 bug. I need to do that and then it will work. This is an order of operations issue, I think.

development_findings.summary: Kaze decided against adding puzzle elements to the game, stating that it is a 'pure platformer' and puzzles would be contrary to its basic design.
The boss version of the Raven will be an actual, non-ice raven and will likely be black to facilitate a cutscene involving moon and cosmic elements.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses that developing a game of this scale is an immense and challenging undertaking.
context_findings.quote: Making this game is honestly like scaling 50 Everests. That pretty much encapsulates how I feel about making video games.

context_findings.summary: Kaze states his design philosophy prioritizes new ideas and concepts over pure platforming challenges, which is why he doesn't typically enjoy most 'Brutal Mario' style hacks.
context_findings.quote: To me, games is about experiencing new ideas and concepts. And I don't really get that from this axe.

context_findings.summary: Kaze demonstrates a deep, practical knowledge of N64 programming by reciting complex GameShark cheat codes from memory, explaining it's possible by knowing the underlying assembly instructions.
Kaze fulfilled a channel point redemption by drinking a mixture of quark and milk on stream, which he described as disgusting but healthy.
Kaze estimates the game is still two to three years away from completion, citing a significant amount of content that still needs to be created and tested.
context_findings.quote: I'm working on the 13th level. But I still need to do boza levels and two side levels. And a huge part of the overworld.

biobak.summary: Biobak suggested that the new Raven enemies should pop out of the ground like ice minions, an idea Kaze immediately adopted for being both cooler and simpler to program than his original pathing concept.
biobak.quote: You mean like pop out of ground, walk forwards, around the corner and then just disappear back in? Yeah, that would be so much easier.

zeina.summary: Zeina created the 3D model for the new Raven enemy.
Zeina participated in the design discussion about the Raven's appearance, clarifying whether it should be made of ice or snow after the team decided to change its concept.
zeina.quote: Or are you thinking he should be made out of snow?

zeina.summary: Zeina prepared the 'cum shake' (quark and milk) for Kaze to drink on stream for a channel point redemption.

key_stories.title: The Dive Jump Dilemma
key_stories.summary: Kaze reveals he had a conversation with developer Dan Salvato about the game's dive jump mechanic. He's now considering nerfing it because it allows players to easily correct mistakes mid-air, which goes against the core design philosophy of commitment in Mario 64. He solicited feedback from his viewers on a potential change.
key_stories.challenge: A core movement mechanic, the dive jump, might be too powerful and violate the design principles of the original game it's based on.
key_stories.process: Kaze had an off-stream conversation with developer Dan Salvato, who pointed out the inconsistency. Kaze agreed with the critique and presented the problem and a potential solution (limiting the angle change) to his viewers to solicit opinions.
key_stories.outcome: The decision is unresolved. Kaze is gathering feedback and considering implementing a version with a much smaller angle change to reward experienced players without it being a 'get out of jail free' card for everyone.
key_stories.key_quote: I talked to Dan Salvato and he said that the dive jump we have is kind of like against the design of Mario 64 and I can kind of see it. The thing is, this lets you change your angle in midair and nothing else in Mario 64 does.

key_stories.title: Implementing the Ice Raven Enemy
key_stories.summary: Kaze implemented a new Raven enemy, but the initial pathing concept was complicated. A collaborative suggestion from Biobak to have them emerge from the ground simplified the design. Kaze then worked through numerous technical hurdles to create a functional version of the enemy by the end of the stream.
key_stories.challenge: To implement the new Raven enemy for the ice level in a way that was thematically appropriate but not overly complex to program.
key_stories.process: Kaze imported Zeina's model and initially struggled with a complex pathfinding concept. Team member Biobak suggested having them pop out of the ground like ice minions. Kaze embraced this simpler, cooler idea and then spent the stream implementing it, overcoming numerous bugs related to their appearance, movement, turning, and interaction.
key_stories.outcome: A functional Raven enemy that spawns from surfaces, walks a pre-determined path with turns, and then despawns. The enemy's code is complete and ready for placement in the final level.
key_stories.key_quote: Shit, you're right. Just like ice minions popping out. But what do they do then? Do they just pop out, walk a path and then disappear? Oh, that would be so much easier to program.

open_questions.topic: Dan Salvato's Influence on Game Physics
open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that Dan Salvato's feedback is making him reconsider the powerful dive jump mechanic, as it goes against the 'commitment' philosophy of SM64 jumps.
questions: Could you walk us through your full conversation with Dan Salvato about the game's design?
How much does feedback from other established developers influence your own design philosophy?
What was the final decision on the dive jump, and what was the process for arriving at it?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned the standard Raven enemy is a precursor to a boss fight. He stated the boss fight will 'go crazy' and involve 'moon and cosmic elements'.
questions: You said the planned boss fight 'is going to go crazy'. Can you describe the concept for the Raffle the Raven boss fight?
What are the 'moon and cosmic elements' you plan to incorporate into the fight and cutscene?
How does your design process for a major boss fight differ from that of a regular enemy?

open_questions.context: When describing the ice level, Kaze said it will be a 'surreal ice palace with some mindfuck stuff going on.'
questions: What do you mean by 'mindfuck stuff' in the context of the ice palace level design?
What specific gameplay mechanics or visual effects are you planning to create this 'surreal' feeling?
What were the primary inspirations for this level's aesthetic and design?

open_questions.context: Biobak provided a key suggestion for the Raven's behavior that Kaze immediately adopted because it was 'cooler and easier to program.'
questions: Can you describe the typical creative feedback loop between you, Biobak, and Zeina?
How often does a spontaneous suggestion from a team member completely change the direction of a feature you're working on?
What's an example of a time you had to reject a suggestion from the team, and what was the reasoning?

open_questions.context: Kaze began the stream by mentioning he spent time refactoring the RTUI codebase to improve stability and fix crashes.
questions: You mentioned refactoring the codebase. What were the biggest technical debts or challenges you were trying to solve?
What specific improvements in stability or performance came from that work?
How do you balance working on new features versus maintaining and improving the existing code for a long-term project?
